segments.text: And he took him everywhere he went with him.
He went and took my father.
And because he was a sharpshooter in the Army, he was discharged six months ahead of time.
And he went on home, back to his hometown and married my mother.
And stayed there a very little short while.
They decided to come to the United States because the taxes were so high in a way they couldn't hardly live with what little they were making.
And they had to pay so much duties and different things for different kinds of taxes that they just couldn't make it.
So they moved to Louisiana, landed in New Orleans.
And they had one little girl.
They brought from Italy, and one of them, I mean, the only one that was born in Italy that came to him came to Louisiana.
And they worked in the cane fields.
The day, they put in about anywhere from 12 to maybe 11 hours a day, and then at night, 50 cents a day.
And then at night, he would go work at the sugar mill, and the sugar mill, they paid him 50 cents until 12 o'clock at night.
And the next morning, of course, he had to go back to work at 6 o'clock.
He had a brother-in-law here in Bryan that was farming.
He probably had his own land at the time, but I don't remember whether he did or not.
But anyway, they asked him to come move in Bryan with him.
So when they got to Bryan, they started farming on different places on 3rd and 4th, I mean on Havas, until they was able to buy him some mule.
And then he went to work on third and fourth, what they call.
I guess what it was, the corn, the owner of the land got one-third, and the man that was working the land got two-thirds.
And the cotton, they got three-fourths, and the man that owned the land got a fourth.
So he worked like that from one place to another.
He just missed the 99 flood.
He was in what they call right at the bottom around Copy Bridge somewhere.
I have never been able to locate where they did live because actually they didn't go back there for a long time.
I don't doubt whether they ever went back there.
So they moved just ahead of the flood, and they worked...
farmed until 1902, renting land and farming them third and fourth.
And in 1902, we bought a farm.
I was born in 1900, and then when I was two years old, we bought this farm.
It was between, on Dilly Short there, between two weeks and creeks.
And I stayed with him and went part of the time, went to school, and part-time worked with him in the field.
until we paid the land, by the way, in a couple of years.
And we had a very good friend of the family of the Carrabbas and the Whittyards who were akin to us with a man named Sam Parker Sr. And he loaned us the money to buy the land.
And in a couple of years, we had it paid for.
So I went on from then on until I was gone and went
We moved to Dallas one time.
I might mention this ahead of before, but we moved to Dallas and Memphis, Tennessee and Memphis, Tennessee, because we had a lot of snow and the boys couldn't get no jobs.
We stayed there about a month and went back and moved to Dallas and opened a grocery store.
And since the my brother was old enough to begin to notice girls, they forgot about the store and left me and my dad around.
My dad couldn't speak English.
And I was too young to run the store, so we was just about to go broke, and we decided to come back to Brian.
So we lost a whole year's crop, plus about $2,000 for the trip and back.
But anyway, we come back and got our land back.
And the man that we rented the land to made the biggest crop that would have been made in that place.
I think he made 39 or 49 bales.
I don't remember.
So we lost that crop.
Then we had to buy a team again.
And when we left, we sold it for nothing.
Then they'd buy new again, and it cost us quite a bit of money.
But anyway, I think I mentioned this before.
My mother was very conservative, and she had $4,000.
No one knew but her.
And we took that $4,000 and bought all our teams and got started back in the little cattle business, which
You would buy a calf then for about three and a half, four dollars, a pig for about two and a half, three or four dollars.
And then in 1920, my brother married in 1919, and I got married in 1920.
And I farmed three years after that, after I'd gotten married.
Two years in my father-in-law's place, who was Lou Bridgetti.
And one year in John Grover's place.
And I made the best crop there in this place that I ever made in all these rest of the two years.
And right around 1923, I think it was probably September or October, I moved in town.
And I went to work for Lawrence Grocery Company, worked for them 26 or 27 years.
And then Lawrence Grocery Company, of course, I might have mentioned this before, they sold out.
And I went to work for Kimball.
And I've always wanted a retail grocery store.
And I worked for Kimball, and it wasn't a very satisfactory position.
I was a salesman, by the way.
I had my vacation coming, and I told the boss that I was quitting, but I wanted to take my vacation that I had coming, which was two weeks.
And I took 10 days of it and went to California to see my sister.
And from there, we bought this store, which was on 25th and San Jacinto.
We stayed there and by that time the Army Air Base opened again and we'd done fairly good business and made a little extra money.
Did you have any trouble getting this first job because of being Italian?
No, I did not because
The only, because there's a couple of friends of mine, John Collette and Jack Shimon, who were real good friends of mine.
Well, in fact, we were a little bit kin, kind of distant kin.
And they were trading with Lawrence Grocery Company, and they asked Mr. Lawrence if they needed a man.
I wanted to move to town.
It was very easy.
I went, the boss interviewed me and showed me all that heavy stuff I had to live.
But through a good friend of mine there, I didn't do much of that.
He finally got to liking me, and I...
He gave me an easy job, finally became an assistant shipping clerk.
He was a shipping clerk.
And from then he quit and I got his job and was making a little more money.

But you talk about discrimination, I probably said this back there before, that there's always been a little discrimination between most any of the, in this part of the country you find discrimination against Italians,
In the other parts of the country, you might find discrimination against the Polish or the Bohemians or whoever you want to call it.
But still, now, you can notice that there still is a little discrimination when it comes to election, when it comes to social affairs.
Well, most times, you can notice a little discrimination, even today.
But it's not like it was because there's business interest innocent to the fact that we want their business and they want our business.
And they don't show it as bad.
After all, you know, we're all foreigners in this country.
You know, she was born in England and came down here.
But anyway, we're still foreigners.
And they just, because they happened to come here a little bit before we did or before the other guy did, there's no sense in it.
And as far as discrimination with the black people, we had them working for us on the farm, and we played ball.
I belonged to the team.
There was three of us, me and myself and two brothers, and the rest of them was black.
We were playing baseball.
How'd you do?
We done fine.
We got along fine.
Never had a bit of trouble with them, either of them today.
Very few of them live in, I think, one of the guys that still live in is Sun Bell, who has resigned from the city council just this year.
And we're still friends.
I invited him to my house one time to come watch TV, and he
He wanted to go around the back door.
I said, no, you come in the front door.
I said, that front door is open for anybody, any of my friends.
And he never did forget that.
It was the first time I'd been in a white man's house.
He said I didn't have to go in from the back door.
But it's not, the discrimination now is not too bad with the Italian people or different nationalities.
There's still a lot of discrimination with the blacks.
Is there a large Italian population here in Bryan?
Oh, it was, but most people, as they got married, there were no jobs for them here because Bryan was rather small.
They would all move to Houston.
Sometimes I think that 90% of the Italian people in Houston come from Bryan.
Of course, now all the old folks have passed away.
Sometimes I feel like I'm about the oldest one in the Italian race.
Descent's here, but I'm not.
It's two older than I am.
But my brother, he's 87 years old.
And then there's an old man, Mr. John Palisotto.
He's 92, I believe.
And, of course, I'm going to be 76 in August.
And I'm getting up to the age.
I don't know why.
I don't know anything else I could tell you.
Do you have any plans?
Do I have any plans?
Yeah.
My only plan now is mostly, I'm not saying this boasting or anything, is serving God and working with the church.
That's all I want.
Most of that's my biggest job.
Go there and...
straighten out things for them in the evening, get ready for the morning, for the night service.
We have service at 7 o'clock.
And I have everything ready for the priest as they come in now.
All they have to do is start with the service.
And take care of the countenance, the board of countenance over the call.
And they don't have to worry about anything.
And I just love doing it.
Then I usher every Sunday, every Saturday evening at 7 o'clock, then Sunday at 7 o'clock.
And one thing they won't trust me is with the money.
They do their own counting.
They have a bunch of counts of money.
And every collection, every service, you know, they have a collection.
And not each one count their own money.
But I don't count any of the other money, nor the night, because I don't have time.
Because I've got to be cleaning up after they get through, put stuff away, and get it out of the way for the day.
They may have a way with something.
And my plans are just living and trying to live the best peaceful life I can and wait for the good Lord to come home, boy.
That's about all I know, unless you want to ask me anything else.
No, I think that'll be it.
Thank you very much.
